output.rationale: This appears to be an original epidemiological study examining PM2.5 (along with PM10) exposure and respiratory hospital admissions using distributed lag non-linear models, which is consistent with time-series methodology. The study reports quantitative associations and risk estimates for respiratory diseases (asthma and COPD). While the abstract mentions both PM10 and PM2.5, PM2.5 is explicitly analyzed as one of the exposures. The study reports significant effects and risk changes, suggesting effect estimates with statistical measures are provided.

This is an original epidemiological study examining PM2.5 exposure and asthma-related ED visits in children. The study uses mixed-effects quasi-Poisson regression on time-series data (daily visits over 2010-2015), which is consistent with a time-series design. Asthma exacerbations requiring ED visits qualify as respiratory emergency department visits. While the abstract does not explicitly report RR/OR with confidence intervals, it reports a statistically significant association (P<10-4) and mentions the relationship can be described by a sigmoid function with specific parameters, suggesting quantitative effect estimates are available in the full text. The study meets all major inclusion criteria.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using case-crossover design, (2) includes PM2.5 as exposure, (3) asthma hospitalization is a respiratory hospitalization outcome, (4) time-stratified case-crossover design, (5) reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% CI for PM2.5 (0.31%, 95% CI 0.24-0.37% per 1-μg/m3 increase), and (6) published in English.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original case-crossover epidemiological study, (2) PM2.5 was the primary pollutant (62% of days) and pollutant-specific analyses were conducted, (3) outcomes include both respiratory ED visits and hospitalizations for asthma, (4) case-crossover design, (5) reports odds ratios with 95% confidence intervals, and (6) published in English. Although the primary exposure is AQI, the study specifically analyzes PM2.5 as one of the pollutants and states 'the association was strongest for PM2.5.'

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using a novel statistical method; (2) exposure is PM2.5; (3) outcome includes respiratory hospitalizations (32 respiratory diagnoses); (4) study design is case-crossover (time-stratified); (5) reports associations (positive associations for 31 of 32 respiratory outcomes) which would include effect estimates; (6) published in English. While the study also examines cardiovascular outcomes, it explicitly analyzes respiratory hospitalizations as a key outcome.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using time-series analysis with DLNM, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly analyzed as one of the exposures with specific effect estimates reported, (3) the outcome is hospital admissions for respiratory diseases, (4) the study design is time-series, (5) relative risks with 95% confidence intervals are reported (RR=1.030, 95% CI: 1.012-1.049 for PM2.5 at lag 07), and (6) the article is in English. Although multiple air pollutants are examined, PM2.5 is specifically included with quantitative results.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly analyzed as one of the exposures, (3) outcome includes both respiratory ED visits (bronchiolitis presentations) and hospitalizations, (4) case-crossover design is explicitly stated, (5) odds ratios with quantitative effect estimates are reported (>10% increased risk for PM2.5, up to 30% for NO2), and (6) published in English. The study examines multiple pollutants including PM2.5, which is acceptable per inclusion criteria.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using time-series analysis, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly analyzed as one of the exposures, (3) the outcome is respiratory hospitalizations (acute upper respiratory infections), (4) it uses a time-series design with distributional lagged nonlinear models, (5) it reports relative risk values with 95% confidence intervals for PM2.5 (RR=1.0247, 95% CI: 1.0092-1.0405), and (6) it is published in English. The study focuses on children's hospitalizations for AURI in relation to PM2.5 and other air pollutants.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study, (2) exposure is PM2.5, (3) outcome includes respiratory hospitalizations and ED visits, (4) study design is case-crossover as explicitly stated, (5) reports odds ratios with 95% confidence intervals, and (6) published in English. While the population is specific (childhood cancer survivors), this does not violate any exclusion criteria, and the study examines the PM2.5-respiratory hospitalization association which is the focus of the review.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a case-crossover design, examines PM2.5 exposure (among other pollutants), reports respiratory hospitalizations (bronchiolitis) as the outcome, and provides odds ratios with 95% confidence intervals for PM2.5 (OR=1.04 [1.02-1.06]).

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original case-crossover epidemiological study examining PM2.5 (fine particulate matter) exposure and respiratory hospitalizations in children. The study reports odds ratios with 95% confidence intervals for the association between PM2.5 and respiratory hospitalizations. The abstract is in English and provides quantitative effect estimates.

While this study meets several inclusion criteria (time-series design, PM2.5 exposure, reports RR with effect estimates), the outcome is hospitalization specifically for SARS-CoV-2/COVID-19 infection rather than general respiratory hospitalizations. COVID-19 hospitalizations represent a specific infectious disease outcome that differs from the broader category of respiratory hospitalizations typically examined in PM2.5 systematic reviews. The research question focuses on air pollution's association with COVID-19 disease severity/hospitalization rather than respiratory morbidity in general.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using time-series design, (2) includes PM2.5 as exposure, (3) outcome is asthma emergency department visits (a respiratory outcome), (4) uses time-series models, (5) reports rate ratios with 95% credible intervals (e.g., RR=1.016, 95% CI: 1.008-1.025 for PM2.5), and (6) published in English in a peer-reviewed journal.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using case-crossover design, examines PM2.5 exposure, reports both respiratory ED visits and hospitalizations as outcomes, and provides quantitative effect estimates (incidence rate ratios with 95% CIs). The study reports IRRs of 1.043 (95% CI: 1.000-1.089) for ED presentations and 1.013 (95% CI: 0.971-1.056) for hospital admissions per 10 μg/m3 increase in PM2.5.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly studied as one of the exposures, (3) the outcome is hospital admissions for respiratory diseases, (4) it uses a time-series study design with generalized additive models and distributed lag nonlinear models, (5) it reports quantitative effect estimates (relative risk and percent increases in risk with specific values mentioned in the abstract), and (6) it is published in English. While the study examines multiple pollutants and temperature, PM2.5 is specifically analyzed and reported.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study; (2) PM2.5 is explicitly mentioned as an exposure; (3) respiratory disease hospitalizations are the outcome; (4) time-series analysis with GAM is the stated study design; (5) the abstract indicates that PM2.5 was associated with increased risks of hospitalization, suggesting quantitative effect estimates were reported; (6) the article appears to be in English. While PM10 is also analyzed, PM2.5 is clearly one of the exposures examined.

This is an original epidemiological study using a case-crossover design examining PM2.5 exposure (specifically wildfire smoke PM2.5) and hospitalizations for both cardiovascular and respiratory diseases. The study reports relative risks with confidence intervals for respiratory outcomes including acute respiratory infections, pneumonia, COPD, asthma, and other respiratory diseases. While it also examines cardiovascular outcomes, the inclusion of respiratory hospitalizations as outcomes makes it relevant for the review.

This is an original epidemiological study examining PM2.5 exposure and respiratory hospitalizations (URTI). It uses a time-series design (generalized additive Poisson model with daily data), reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% CI (0.84% increase per 10 μg/m³, 95% CI 0.05-1.64%), and examines hospital admissions and emergency room visits. Upper respiratory tract infections are respiratory conditions warranting hospitalization, meeting the outcome criteria.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) It is an original epidemiological study using time-series analysis; (2) PM2.5 is explicitly analyzed as one of multiple pollutant exposures; (3) The outcome is respiratory hospital admissions for asthma and COPD; (4) Study design is time-series; (5) Quantitative risk ratios with 95% confidence intervals are reported for PM2.5 (asthma: RR 95% CI 0.981-1.148; COPD: RR 95% CI 0.966-1.019); (6) Published in English. Although the PM2.5 results were null findings, the study still provides valid effect estimates for the systematic review.

While this study meets most inclusion criteria (original epidemiological study, PM2.5 exposure, respiratory hospitalization outcome, quantitative effect estimates with CI reported), it fails the study design criterion. The abstract explicitly describes this as a 'retrospective cohort study' rather than a time-series or case-crossover design. Although distributed lag models were used to analyze daily county-level hospitalization rates (which has time-series characteristics), the fundamental study design is stated as cohort, which does not meet the strict inclusion criteria requiring time-series or case-crossover designs.

While this is an original epidemiological study with PM2.5 exposure (from wildfire smoke), time-series design, and reports effect estimates with confidence intervals, the PRIMARY outcomes are cardiovascular and cerebrovascular ED visits. Although respiratory ED visits are mentioned as a secondary outcome (RR 1.18 for adults >65 years), the study's main focus is on cardiovascular and cerebrovascular outcomes, as stated in the title, background, and conclusions. This does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring respiratory hospitalization/ED visit as the primary outcome.

This is an original epidemiological study using a time-series design (daily data with distributed lag models and quasi-Poisson regression) that examines PM2.5 exposure and respiratory ED visits (specifically pneumonia, which is a respiratory condition). The study reports quantitative effect estimates with confidence intervals (RR for pneumonia: 1.071, 95% CI: 1.025-1.118). While the study also examines cardiovascular outcomes and other pollutants, it meets all inclusion criteria for the respiratory component.

Although this study examines PM2.5 exposure and respiratory (pneumonia) hospitalizations with quantitative effect estimates, the study design is a prospective cohort rather than time-series or case-crossover as required by the inclusion criteria. The study follows 433,032 participants prospectively and uses DLNM modeling, which differs from the specified acceptable study designs.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using generalized additive models, (2) exposure is PM2.5 and source-specific PM2.5, (3) outcome is respiratory emergency room visits (ERVs), (4) the use of lag structures and generalized additive models indicates a time-series design, (5) reports relative risks with 95% confidence intervals (e.g., RR = 1.011, 95%CI: 1.002, 1.020), and (6) appears to be published in English. The study examines short-term associations between PM2.5 and respiratory emergency department visits, which aligns with the systematic review objectives.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly included as one of the exposures analyzed, (3) the outcome is respiratory hospital admissions, (4) it uses a case-crossover design, (5) it reports percentage change in odds with 95% CI (equivalent to OR), and (6) it is published in English. Although multiple pollutants are examined, PM2.5 is specifically analyzed and reported.

While this is an original time-series study with PM2.5 exposure and quantitative effect estimates with confidence intervals, the outcome is hospitalization for rheumatoid arthritis-associated interstitial lung disease (RA-ILD), which is a specific autoimmune/rheumatologic condition with secondary lung involvement, not general respiratory hospitalizations. The review targets respiratory hospitalizations (e.g., asthma, COPD, pneumonia, general respiratory diseases), not autoimmune diseases with pulmonary manifestations.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a case-crossover design, examines PM2.5 exposure, investigates respiratory ED visits (including asthma/wheeze, bronchitis, pneumonia, and upper respiratory infections), reports odds ratios with 95% confidence intervals, and is published in English in a peer-reviewed journal.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) exposure includes PM2.5, (3) outcomes are respiratory hospitalizations and ED visits for asthma and COPD, (4) uses time-stratified case-crossover design, (5) reports excess rates with confidence intervals (e.g., ER = 2.1%, 95% CI = 0.7%, 3.6%), and (6) published in English. No exclusion criteria apply.

Although the title mentions 'hospitalization', the abstract clearly describes the outcome as 'outpatient visits' for upper respiratory tract infections, not hospitalizations or emergency department visits. The study examines outpatient clinic visits, which does not meet the inclusion criteria requiring respiratory hospitalization or ED visits as the outcome.

This is an original epidemiological study examining PM2.5 exposure and respiratory outcomes including both ED visits and hospitalizations. The study uses Poisson regression on daily counts, which is characteristic of time-series design. Multiple quantitative effect estimates (RR) with 95% CIs are reported for respiratory outcomes including respiratory disease overall, asthma, and CLRD. Meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 (along with other pollutants) as exposure and AECOPD hospitalizations (a respiratory hospitalization outcome) as the outcome. The study reports quantitative effect estimates (RR and RERI) with 95% confidence intervals. Although the study focuses on interaction effects with temperature and analyzes multiple pollutants, PM2.5 is explicitly included as one of the exposures analyzed, meeting the inclusion criteria.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a time-series design to examine the association between PM2.5 exposure and respiratory hospital admissions in Kuwait. The study reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% confidence intervals (1.61% increase per 10 μg/m3, 95% CI = 0.87, 2.35%). The exposure is clearly PM2.5, the outcome is respiratory hospitalizations, and effect estimates are provided. The study appears to be published in English.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using case-crossover design, (2) exposure is source-specific PM2.5, (3) outcomes include respiratory hospitalizations and ED visits for influenza and pneumonia, (4) case-crossover design as specified, (5) reports excess rates with 95% CIs (e.g., ER=9.2%, 95% CI: 4.3%, 14.3%), and (6) published in English. The study examines PM2.5 as the primary exposure with source apportionment, which is acceptable per inclusion criteria.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using generalized additive models with quasi-Poisson regression, which is a time-series design; (2) PM2.5 is explicitly analyzed as one of multiple air pollutants; (3) the outcome is emergency department visits for upper respiratory tract infection, which qualifies as respiratory ED visits; (4) the study design is time-series based on daily counts; (5) quantitative effect estimates with 95% CI are reported (5.302% increase, 95% CI: 3.202, 7.445 per 10 µg/m3 PM2.5); (6) the abstract is in English. While the outcome is specifically URTI rather than all respiratory conditions, upper respiratory tract infections are a legitimate respiratory outcome for ED visits.

This is an original epidemiological study examining PM2.5 (among other pollutants) as an exposure and respiratory hospitalizations (pneumonia and asthma) as outcomes in children. The study uses a generalized additive model approach consistent with time-series analysis. It reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% confidence intervals for PM2.5 (2.22% increase per 10-unit increase, 95%CI: 0.64%, 3.82%). The study meets all inclusion criteria.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using time-series design, (2) exposure is PM2.5, (3) outcome is asthma emergency room admissions which qualifies as respiratory hospitalization/ED visit, (4) time-series study design, (5) reports percent increase with 95% CI (7.2%, 95% CI 1.7-13.1%), and (6) appears to be in English. Asthma is a respiratory condition and emergency room admissions are consistent with the outcome of interest.

This is an original case-crossover study that explicitly examines PM2.5 exposure (among other pollutants) and hospital admissions for interstitial lung diseases, which are respiratory conditions. The study reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% CIs. While the abstract emphasizes SO2 and NO2 findings, PM2.5 was measured and analyzed as stated in the methods. ILD hospitalizations qualify as respiratory hospitalizations. Meets all inclusion criteria.

This is a time-series study examining respiratory hospitalizations with PM2.5 as one of multiple exposures. However, the abstract does not report the specific effect estimate (RR with CI) for PM2.5 and respiratory hospitalizations - only results for NO2, ozone, and noise are presented. The study meets criteria 1-4, but criterion 5 cannot be verified from the abstract alone as the PM2.5-respiratory hospitalization association is not explicitly reported.

This study meets the inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a time-series design with generalized additive models and distributed lag models. The exposure includes PM2.5 (among other pollutants). The outcome is respiratory hospitalization specifically for COPD patients. The study reports quantitative effect estimates (percentage increases in daily admissions: 0.086-0.109%). While the abstract doesn't explicitly mention confidence intervals, the methodology and reported significant results suggest effect estimates with uncertainty measures are likely reported in the full text.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study, (2) PM2.5 is one of the exposures examined, (3) the outcome is respiratory hospitalizations, (4) it uses a case-crossover design, (5) it reports percentage increases with 95% confidence intervals (equivalent to effect measures), and (6) it is published in English. Although the study also examines PM2.5-10, PM2.5 is explicitly included as a separate exposure.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original ecological time-series study, (2) the exposure is PM2.5, (3) the outcome is respiratory hospitalizations (pneumonia, acute bronchitis, bronchiolitis, and asthma), (4) the study design is time-series, (5) it reports relative risks with values (RR = 1.017 at lag 2, RR = 1.022 at lag 5, RR = 1.020 at lag 7), and (6) it is published in English (with Portuguese translation). The study uses appropriate methods including generalized additive Poisson regression with appropriate adjustments for confounders.

Study meets most inclusion criteria: original epidemiological study, PM2.5 exposure, respiratory hospitalizations outcome, and reports RR with CI. However, the study design is described as 'difference-in-differences approach generalized to multiple spatial units and time periods with distributed lag non-linear models' rather than explicitly stating time-series or case-crossover. While this approach with daily data across regions and time periods shares characteristics with time-series analysis, it is not clearly identified as one of the required study designs (time-series or case-crossover). The difference-in-differences framework is a distinct causal inference method.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a case-crossover design; examines PM2.5 as one of multiple exposures; outcome is respiratory emergency department visits; reports quantitative associations (positive results with specific lag periods); and appears to be published in English. While the abstract does not explicitly state effect measures like OR or RR, the mention of 'positive results' and 'associations' with specific lag periods strongly suggests quantitative effect estimates are reported in the full text.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study, (2) exposure is PM2.5, (3) outcome is respiratory hospitalization (ALRI hospitalizations including CAP, AECB, AECOPD, AEB), (4) study design is explicitly stated as time-series, (5) reports percent increases with 95% confidence intervals (convertible to relative risks), and (6) published in English.

This is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 exposure and hospital admissions for multiple disease categories including respiratory diseases. It reports quantitative effect estimates with confidence intervals (e.g., 0.21% increase with 95% CI for digestive diseases). Although the study examines multiple disease outcomes beyond respiratory hospitalizations, respiratory hospitalizations are explicitly included as one of the 7 major disease categories analyzed. The study meets all inclusion criteria: original epidemiological research, PM2.5 exposure, includes respiratory hospitalizations as an outcome, time-series design, reports effect estimates with confidence intervals, and is in English.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Original epidemiological study using time-series analysis with generalized additive Poisson regression; (2) Exposure includes PM2.5 (along with PM2.5-bound PAHs); (3) Outcome is respiratory emergency department visits for asthma, which qualifies as respiratory ED visits; (4) Time-series design using daily counts; (5) Reports relative risks with 95% confidence intervals for PM2.5 and asthma ERVs; (6) Published in English. While the study focuses on PM2.5-bound PAHs, it explicitly reports associations between PM2.5 itself and asthma ERVs, making it relevant for the review.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) PM2.5 exposure is explicitly investigated, (3) outcome is hospital admissions for respiratory diseases, (4) time-series study design clearly stated, (5) quantitative effect estimates reported as percentage change with 95% CI (PM2.5: 0.755%; 95% CI: 0.422, 1.089%), and (6) published in English. All exclusion criteria are avoided.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) includes PM2.5 as exposure, (3) outcome is asthma-related emergency department visits (AEDv) which qualifies as respiratory ED visits, (4) uses time-series design with Poisson regression, (5) reports quantitative RR with specific effect estimates (4.4% increase per IQR of PM2.5), and (6) published in English. Although multiple pollutants are analyzed, PM2.5 is explicitly included with separate effect estimates.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) It is an original epidemiological study using case-crossover design with conditional logistic regression; (2) PM2.5 is explicitly analyzed as one of the exposures; (3) The outcome includes asthma-related hospital admissions and emergency department visits, which are respiratory hospitalizations/ED visits; (4) Study design is case-crossover; (5) Effect estimates with 95% confidence intervals are reported; (6) Published in English. While the study examines multiple pollutants (PM2.5, ultrafine particles, NOx, CO), PM2.5 is specifically mentioned and analyzed.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using a generalized additive model (GAM), which is characteristic of time-series analysis; (2) PM2.5 is explicitly examined as an exposure; (3) respiratory hospitalizations are included as an outcome with specific effect estimates reported (1.03% increase per 10 μg/m3, 95% CI: 0.50%-1.56%); (4) the GAM approach indicates a time-series design; (5) quantitative effect estimates with confidence intervals are provided; (6) the abstract is in English and appears to be from a peer-reviewed publication.

This is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 (among other particle metrics) and hospital admissions including respiratory outcomes. The abstract mentions 'emergency admissions to hospital' and states that 'secondary pollutants, especially nonprimary PM2.5, nitrate and sulfate, were more important for respiratory outcomes,' indicating respiratory hospitalizations were analyzed. While the abstract primarily reports cardiovascular results, it explicitly states that PM2.5 associations with respiratory outcomes were examined. The study uses appropriate methodology (Poisson regression time-series) and appears to report quantitative effect estimates with confidence intervals.

This is an original time-series study using GAMs that examines PM2.5 exposure and multiple health outcomes including respiratory hospitalizations. The study reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% CIs. While it examines multiple disease categories, it specifically reports effects on respiratory system hospitalizations (NO2 effect: 1.36%, 95%CI: 0.74-1.98%), and PM2.5 is one of the main exposures analyzed. The study meets all inclusion criteria.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) examines PM2.5 exposure, (3) outcome is respiratory hospitalization and ED visits for asthma exacerbations, (4) uses time-series study design with Poisson regression, (5) reports relative risk with confidence intervals (RR=1.24, 1.12, 1.31 for different lag periods), and (6) published in English. The study specifically reports quantitative effect estimates for PM2.5 and respiratory outcomes.

While this is a time-series study examining respiratory ED visits with effect estimates reported, the primary exposures of interest are precipitation and temperature on thunderstorm days, not PM2.5. PM2.5 was included as a control/confounding variable in the model, and the results explicitly state that PM2.5 levels were not significantly associated with asthma ED visits on thunderstorm days. The study does not report PM2.5 as a main exposure with its own effect estimate for the association with respiratory outcomes.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using a time-series design with generalized additive model; (2) PM2.5 is one of the exposures analyzed; (3) the outcome is respiratory hospitalizations (acute lower respiratory tract infections including pneumonia and bronchitis); (4) it reports relative risks with 95% confidence intervals for PM2.5 (RR=1.0064, 95% CI 1.0004-1.0124 for pneumonia and RR=1.0133, 95% CI 1.0025-1.0242 for bronchitis); (5) it is published in English. Although multiple pollutants are studied, PM2.5 is specifically included with quantitative estimates.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a time-stratified case-crossover design; examines PM2.5 exposure (along with PM10); focuses on respiratory hospitalizations for asthma and COPD; reports odds ratios with 95% confidence intervals; and appears to be published in English.

This is an original epidemiological study examining PM2.5 (along with UFP) as an exposure. It reports respiratory hospital admissions as an outcome with quantitative effect estimates (7.5% increase with 95% CI [4.9-10.2%] for respiratory admissions per PM2.5 increase). The study design is time-series based on daily counts analyzed with Poisson regression models. All inclusion criteria are met.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a time-series design with Poisson regression, examines PM2.5 exposure, reports respiratory hospital admissions as the outcome, and provides quantitative effect estimates (percentage increases in hospitalization rates per 10 μg/m3 increase in PM2.5) for different racial/ethnic groups and overall population. The study is published in English.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) exposure is PM2.5, (3) outcome includes respiratory hospitalizations/admissions, (4) uses a time-stratified case-crossover design, (5) reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% CIs (1.74% increase per 10 μg/m3 PM2.5 for respiratory admissions, 95% CI: 1.41-2.07%), and (6) published in English. The study examines both cardiovascular and respiratory admissions, but respiratory outcomes are clearly analyzed and reported separately.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) exposure is PM2.5, (3) outcome includes respiratory hospitalizations (159,365 admissions), (4) uses time-stratified case-crossover design, (5) reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% CI (1.95% increase per 10 μg/m3, 95% CI 1.63-2.27% for respiratory diseases), and (6) published in English.

While this is a time-series study examining respiratory hospitalizations with effect estimates reported, the primary exposure is particle oxidative potential (OP), not PM2.5 mass concentration itself. The study specifically investigates OP as a chemical characteristic of PM rather than PM2.5 exposure per se. The exposure metric is % loss of antioxidant per m3, not PM2.5 concentration.

This is an original epidemiological study examining the association between fine particulate matter (PM2.5) from various sources and emergency department visits for pediatric asthma. It uses a time-series design with Poisson generalized linear models, reports rate ratios with 95% confidence intervals, and meets all inclusion criteria.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Original epidemiological study using GAM for time-series analysis; (2) PM2.5 is explicitly analyzed as exposure; (3) Outcome is respiratory disease hospitalization; (4) GAM suggests time-series design examining short-term effects; (5) Reports percent increase in risk with confidence intervals (1.95% (0.25, 3.67) for PM2.5); (6) Published in English. The study provides quantitative effect estimates for PM2.5 and respiratory hospitalizations.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Original epidemiological study using time-series design, (2) PM2.5 exposure clearly specified, (3) respiratory hospitalizations (asthma) are reported as outcomes alongside cardiovascular outcomes, (4) time-series design explicitly stated, (5) relative risks with 95% confidence intervals are reported (e.g., RR 1.16, 95% CI 1.00 to 1.35 for asthma), and (6) published in English. Although the study examines both respiratory and cardiovascular outcomes, it specifically reports asthma hospitalization data which meets the respiratory hospitalization outcome criterion.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using time-series analysis, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly studied as one of the exposures, (3) outcome is chronic respiratory disease (CRD) hospitalizations, (4) time-series design is clearly stated, (5) quantitative effect estimates (excess risks) with 95% CIs are reported for PM2.5 (2.13%, 95% CI: 0.55%, 3.74% per 10 μg/m3 increase), and (6) published in English. Although multiple pollutants are analyzed, PM2.5 is specifically included and reported.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) exposure is PM2.5, (3) outcome is respiratory healthcare visits/encounters which includes hospitalizations and ED visits, (4) uses case-crossover design which is explicitly specified, (5) reports odds ratios with effect estimates (e.g., '1 µg/m3 in PM2.5 exposure...was associated with increased odds'), and (6) published in English. While the abstract mentions temperature as an effect modifier, PM2.5 is clearly the primary exposure of interest.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using a time-stratified case-crossover design, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly included as one of the exposures analyzed, (3) the outcome is hospitalization for respiratory diseases, (4) the study design is case-crossover, (5) quantitative effect estimates with 95% confidence intervals are reported (OR=1.017, 95%CI: 1.003-1.031 for PM2.5), and (6) the article is published in English. The study specifically reports the association between PM2.5 and respiratory hospitalizations in children with clear effect measures.

This is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 (among other exposures) in relation to respiratory outcomes including ED and inpatient visits for asthma exacerbation. Rate ratios with confidence intervals are reported. While the study focuses on effect modification by viral infections and the primary results shown are for pollen, the abstract indicates PM2.5 was analyzed and the outcomes include both ED and inpatient (hospitalization) visits for a respiratory condition (asthma exacerbation).

This study meets the inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a time-series design (GAM with daily data) examining PM2.5 exposure (among other pollutants) and respiratory hospitalizations (patients with respiratory diseases and comorbid diabetes), and reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% CIs. While the population is restricted to those with diabetes comorbidity, the outcome is still respiratory hospitalization, which meets the criteria.

While this is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 exposure with quantitative effect estimates (RR with CI), the outcome is acute upper respiratory tract infections (AURTIs), which typically refers to infections of the upper airways (pharyngitis, rhinitis, common cold) rather than lower respiratory conditions that typically require hospitalization. The systematic review focuses on respiratory hospitalizations, which generally refer to more severe lower respiratory conditions (pneumonia, COPD exacerbations, asthma). AURTIs are typically less severe conditions, and the distinction between upper and lower respiratory outcomes is clinically meaningful.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using time-series design with generalized additive models, (2) PM2.5 is a primary exposure variable, (3) the outcome is emergency department visits for asthma (respiratory condition), (4) it reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% confidence intervals (e.g., 6.1% increase, CI: 2.1-10.3%), and (5) it is published in English. Although the outcome is ED visits rather than hospitalization, the inclusion criteria explicitly include emergency department visits for respiratory conditions.

This is an original epidemiological study using a case time series design (a variant of time-series analysis) examining PM2.5 exposure and respiratory hospitalizations. It reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% confidence intervals (1.43% increase per 10 μg/m³ PM2.5 increment for respiratory hospitalizations). Although the study also examines cardiovascular outcomes, it meets all inclusion criteria for the respiratory hospitalization component.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a case-crossover design, examines PM2.5 exposure, evaluates respiratory hospitalization (COPD admissions), reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% CI (1.6% increase per 10 μg/m3, 95% CI: 0.6%, 2.7%), and appears to be published in English. COPD hospitalizations are a respiratory outcome relevant to the review.

Although this study examines PM2.5 as one of multiple exposures and uses a case-crossover design with effect estimates, the outcome is 'pediatric asthma visits' which appears to be outpatient visits for asthma exacerbation requiring prednisone treatment, not hospitalizations or ED visits. The results section states no association was found with PM2.5, and the primary focus is on ultrafine particles. The outcome does not meet the inclusion criteria for respiratory hospitalization or ED visit.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using case-crossover design, (2) includes PM2.5 as one of multiple exposures analyzed, (3) outcome is respiratory hospital admissions, (4) case-crossover study design explicitly stated, (5) reports associations/effect estimates for PM2.5 and respiratory admissions with discussion of effect strength and statistical significance, and (6) published in English. The abstract indicates quantitative effect estimates were computed even though specific values are not provided in the abstract.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study comparing PM2.5 exposure metrics, (2) exposure is PM2.5, (3) outcome is COPD hospitalizations (respiratory hospitalization), (4) case-crossover design is explicitly stated, (5) reports odds ratios with 95% confidence intervals (e.g., OR=1.26, 95%CI: 1.06-1.50), and (6) published in English. No exclusion criteria apply.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study, (2) PM2.5 is examined as an exposure, (3) respiratory hospitalizations are included as an outcome (916,388 respiratory admissions identified), (4) case-crossover design is explicitly stated in the title and methods (conditional logistic regression), (5) quantitative effect estimates with 95% CIs are reported (0.26% increase, 95% CI = 0.22%, 0.31% for respiratory admissions per 10 μg/m³ PM2.5), and (6) published in English.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Original epidemiological study using quasi-Poisson regression with distributed lag model, indicating time-series design; (2) PM2.5 is explicitly included as one of the exposures analyzed; (3) Outcome is respiratory hospital admissions (asthma, COPD, bronchiectasis); (4) Time-series study design based on methods description; (5) Reports relative risks with 95% confidence intervals for PM2.5 and respiratory admissions; (6) Published in English. Although multiple pollutants were analyzed, PM2.5-specific results are reported.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a case-crossover design, examines PM2.5 exposure, reports respiratory hospitalizations (pneumonia) as the outcome, and provides quantitative effect estimates with 95% confidence intervals (12% and 4% increases in admissions).

The primary exposure is coarse particles (PM2.5-10), not PM2.5. While the abstract mentions PM2.5 was adjusted for as a confounder, the study's main exposure of interest is coarse particulate matter, which does not meet the inclusion criteria requiring PM2.5 as the primary exposure.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using GAM time-series analysis, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly analyzed as one of multiple exposures, (3) the outcome is hospital admissions for asthma, which is a respiratory hospitalization, (4) the study design is time-series as stated in the title and methods, (5) it reports relative risk values with 95% confidence intervals for PM2.5 (RR=1.015, 95% CI: 1.003-1.028 per 10 μg/m3 increase), and (6) the article appears to be published in English. While the outcome is specifically asthma rather than all respiratory conditions, asthma hospitalizations are a well-established respiratory hospitalization outcome and relevant to the systematic review.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) PM2.5 exposure is explicitly analyzed, (3) respiratory hospitalization and ED visits for COPD exacerbation are the outcomes, (4) time-series design with Poisson regression is clearly stated, (5) relative risk estimates with statistical significance are reported for PM2.5, and (6) published in English. COPD exacerbation requiring hospitalization/ED visit is a respiratory hospitalization outcome.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using time-series design to examine the association between PM2.5 exposure and respiratory emergency department visits. The study reports rate ratios with 95% credible intervals for PM2.5 effects on respiratory ED visits across multiple age groups. Although ozone is also examined, PM2.5 is explicitly analyzed as one of the exposures.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study, (2) the exposure is PM2.5 (source-specific), (3) the outcome includes respiratory emergency department visits, (4) it uses a case-crossover study design, (5) it reports quantitative effect estimates (excess risk) with 95% confidence intervals for respiratory outcomes including all respiratory EDVs and asthma, and (6) it is published in English.

This is an original time-series study examining the association between PM2.5 (among other pollutants) and asthma hospitalizations. The abstract explicitly mentions PM2.5 as one of the exposures analyzed, uses a time-series design with generalized additive models, examines respiratory hospitalizations (asthma), and reports effect estimates with attributable risks. All inclusion criteria are met.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study, (2) PM2.5 is examined as one of the exposures, (3) the outcome is respiratory hospitalizations, (4) the study design is time-series using quasi-Poisson regression with DLNM, (5) it reports relative risks with 95% confidence intervals (RR 1.089, 95% CI 1.001-1.183 for PM2.5), and (6) it is published in English. While the study examines multiple air pollutants, PM2.5 is explicitly analyzed and reported with quantitative effect estimates.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using a time-series design, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly included as one of the exposures, (3) the outcome is hospital admissions for acute bronchitis, which is a respiratory hospitalization, (4) it uses a time-series design with generalized additive models, (5) it reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% confidence intervals (1.23% increase per 10 µg/m3 increase in PM2.5 with 95% CI 0.21-2.26%), and (6) the article is published in English.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using time-series design, examines PM2.5 as one of multiple exposures, reports asthma emergency department visits (a respiratory outcome), provides quantitative effect estimates (rate ratios with confidence intervals as indicated by inverse-variance weighting), and appears to be published in English. Although it examines multiple pollutants, PM2.5 is explicitly included in the analysis.

While this study examines PM2.5 (fine particulate matter) as one exposure and respiratory hospitalizations as the outcome using a time-series design with Poisson regression models, the abstract only reports quantitative effect estimates for temperature (18% increase in risk for 4°C temperature increase), not for PM2.5. The study's primary focus appears to be on temperature effects, with PM2.5 included as a covariate. Without reported effect estimates for PM2.5 on respiratory hospitalizations, this study does not meet inclusion criterion 5 for the systematic review.

This is an original time-series study examining the association between PM2.5 (and ozone) exposure and cardiorespiratory outcomes including respiratory hospitalizations and ED visits. The study reports quantitative risk ratios with specific values for respiratory disease outcomes (e.g., RR=1.020 for respiratory disease-ozone association in ED visits). While the study includes both ozone and PM2.5 and both cardiac and respiratory outcomes, it meets inclusion criteria as PM2.5 is explicitly analyzed as one of the exposures, respiratory outcomes are included, the design is time-series, and effect estimates are reported.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using case time series design, (2) exposure is PM2.5, (3) outcomes include both respiratory hospitalizations and ED visits, (4) study design is time-series (case time series), (5) reports excess relative risks with 95% confidence intervals for respiratory hospitalizations and ED visits, and (6) published in English. The study examines multiple outcomes including respiratory disease which is the focus of the systematic review.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study; (2) includes PM2.5 as exposure; (3) outcome is respiratory hospitalization (COPD exacerbations requiring hospital admission); (4) uses case-crossover design (time-stratified); (5) reports rate ratios with 95% CIs (RR=1.030, 95% CI 1.006-1.055 for PM2.5); (6) published in English (appears to be). Although it also examines other pollutants (PM10, NO2, SO2), PM2.5 is specifically analyzed with quantitative effect estimates.

This is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 exposure and respiratory hospital admissions (along with cardiovascular admissions). The study reports quantitative effect estimates from generalized linear models, analyzes PM2.5 (both total mass and source-specific), includes respiratory hospitalizations as an outcome, uses a time-series design, and appears to be published in English. All inclusion criteria are met.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using generalized additive model with distributed lag model, (2) PM2.5 is included as one of multiple air pollutants examined, (3) outcome is respiratory emergency department visits for pediatric asthma, (4) time-series design (daily ED visits analyzed over time 2016-2018), (5) reports relative risks with 95% confidence intervals for PM2.5 (RR=1.011, 95%CI: 1.002, 1.021), and (6) published in English. Although the outcome is specifically asthma ED visits rather than all respiratory hospitalizations, asthma is a respiratory condition and ED visits are explicitly included in the review criteria.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) PM2.5 is one of the exposures analyzed, (3) outcome is respiratory hospitalization (asthma admissions), (4) study design is time-series/case-crossover as stated in title and abstract, (5) reports rate ratios with 95% CIs for PM2.5 (RR=1.014, 95%CI: 1.000-1.028 per 10 µg/m3), and (6) published in English. Although the title mentions 'case-crossover' and abstract mentions 'time-series analysis', both designs are acceptable per inclusion criteria.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original time-series epidemiological study examining PM2.5 exposure (among other pollutants) and respiratory hospitalizations in children, with quantitative effect estimates (RR=1.089, 95%CI:1.075-1.103 for PM2.5) reported. The outcome is hospitalization for acute lower respiratory infections including pneumonia and bronchiolitis, which are respiratory hospitalizations.

This is an original epidemiological study examining PM2.5 exposure and respiratory hospitalizations (including asthma-related hospitalizations) using time-series methodology with Poisson regression. The study reports percentage increases with 95% CIs for respiratory outcomes. While it also examines cardiovascular outcomes, it includes respiratory hospitalizations which meet the inclusion criteria.

This is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 (among other pollutants) and pediatric emergency room admissions for respiratory reasons. Although the results indicate PM2.5 was not significantly associated with ER admissions, the study meets all inclusion criteria: it analyzed PM2.5 as an exposure, examined respiratory ED visits as an outcome, used time-series methodology with Poisson regression, and reports quantitative effect estimates with confidence intervals. Studies with null findings should be included to avoid publication bias.

While this study uses an interrupted time series design and includes PM2.5 exposure assessment with respiratory hospitalizations as one of the stratified outcomes, it is examining long-term effects (8 years post-fire) rather than the typical short-term associations that characterize time-series studies of PM2.5 and respiratory hospitalizations. The study focuses on the lasting impact of a single environmental disaster event rather than day-to-day or seasonal variations in PM2.5 exposure. Additionally, the abstract does not clearly indicate whether specific effect estimates (RR/OR with CI) for the PM2.5-respiratory hospitalization association are reported, though results are presented for multiple outcomes combined.

This is an original 18-year time-series study examining PM2.5 (specifically organic carbon fraction of PM2.5) exposure in relation to respiratory ED visits among children. The study reports quantitative effect estimates (rate ratios) with 95% confidence intervals for respiratory outcomes including pneumonia, bronchitis/bronchiolitis, and URI. Although multiple pollutants were analyzed, PM2.5 is explicitly included as one of the exposures. All inclusion criteria are met.

Although this is an original time-series study with effect estimates, it fails multiple inclusion criteria: (1) The exposure includes PM10, not PM2.5; (2) The outcomes are pulmonary embolism and venous thrombosis, which are cardiovascular/thrombotic conditions, not respiratory hospitalizations. While pulmonary embolism affects the lungs anatomically, it is a thrombotic disorder, not a respiratory disease like asthma, COPD, or pneumonia.

The study examines the association between particulate matter exposure and suicide deaths, not respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. The outcome (suicide death) does not meet the inclusion criteria requiring respiratory hospitalization/ED visit outcomes. Additionally, the exposure appears to be primarily PM10 rather than PM2.5.

This is a critical review of existing studies, not an original epidemiological study. Additionally, the exposure is PM10 (not PM2.5) and the outcome is mortality (not respiratory hospitalization or ED visit).

This is a systematic review/meta-analysis of existing studies, not an original epidemiological study. Additionally, the outcome is coronary/cardiovascular disease, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visits. The exposure includes PM10 but does not specifically focus on PM2.5.

This is a meta-analysis/systematic review, not an original epidemiological study. Additionally, the outcome is mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visits. The exposure is PM10, not PM2.5.

The outcome is out-of-hospital cardiac arrest of cardiac origin, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visit. Despite meeting criteria for exposure (PM2.5), study design (case-crossover), and having effect estimates with confidence intervals, the outcome does not match the inclusion criteria which specifically requires respiratory hospitalization or ED visits.

This is an animal study (mice) investigating the biological mechanisms of PM2.5-induced lung injury and the protective effects of Astragaloside IV. It is not an epidemiological study examining respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits in humans. The study design is experimental/laboratory-based, not time-series or case-crossover, and does not report epidemiological effect estimates like RR or OR for hospitalization outcomes.

This is explicitly stated to be a review article ('this review is focused on these aspects') rather than an original epidemiological study. It does not report original quantitative effect estimates with confidence intervals for the association between PM2.5 and respiratory hospitalizations/ED visits.

The study examines PM10 exposure, not PM2.5 as required by inclusion criteria. While the outcome (respiratory hospitalization for COPD and asthma) and study design (time-series) are appropriate, the exposure does not meet the specified criteria of PM2.5 or fine particulate matter ≤2.5 µm. PM10 refers to particulate matter ≤10 µm in diameter, which is a different exposure category.

While this is a time-series study examining PM2.5 constituents with quantitative effect estimates, the outcome is cardiovascular hospital admissions, not respiratory hospitalizations. The abstract explicitly states 'cardiovascular hospital admissions' as the main finding. This does not meet the inclusion criteria requiring respiratory hospitalization/ED visit as the outcome.

While this is an original epidemiological study using time-series design with effect estimates, the exposure is PM10 (particulate matter ≤10 μm) rather than PM2.5 (≤2.5 μm). The study does not mention PM2.5 analysis. Additionally, while hospital admissions are mentioned in the outcome, the results emphasize cardio-respiratory mortality and hospital admissions combined, without clearly isolating respiratory hospitalizations specifically.

The study examines PM10 (particulate matter ≤10 μm), not PM2.5 (≤2.5 μm) as required by the inclusion criteria. While the study design is case-crossover, has respiratory hospitalizations as an outcome, and reports quantitative effect estimates, the exposure does not meet the PM2.5 requirement.

The study examines PM10 (particles ≤10 μm) rather than PM2.5 (particles ≤2.5 μm) as the exposure variable. While the study meets other inclusion criteria (original epidemiological study, time-series design, respiratory hospitalizations as outcome, reports RR with confidence intervals, published in English), the exposure does not match the required PM2.5 specification.

This appears to be a health impact assessment or policy evaluation study that uses relative risks from a literature review to estimate avoidable hospitalizations, rather than an original epidemiological study that directly analyzes the association between PM2.5 exposure and respiratory hospitalizations. The abstract states 'A literature review was carried out to determine the appropriate relative risk to be used in the estimations' and focuses on quantifying public health gains from new air quality standards. This does not meet the inclusion criterion of being an original epidemiological study with time-series or case-crossover design.

The study examines PM10 (particles <10 µm) rather than PM2.5 (particles ≤2.5 µm) as the exposure. Additionally, the outcome is emergency ambulance dispatches rather than respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. While respiratory diseases are mentioned, the outcome measure does not match the inclusion criteria which specifically requires respiratory hospitalization or ED visits.

The study examines hospital admissions for ischemic stroke, not respiratory hospitalizations. Although it meets other criteria (original epidemiological study, PM2.5 exposure, case-crossover design, reports RR with CI), the outcome is cardiovascular (stroke) rather than respiratory, which does not meet the inclusion criteria for this systematic review.
Study examines PM10 exposure (not PM2.5) and cardiovascular events (not respiratory outcomes). Fails to meet inclusion criteria for both exposure type and outcome.

The study examines cardiovascular mortality as the outcome, not respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. Although the exposure includes air pollutants and uses a time-series design with distributed lag models, it does not meet the outcome criteria for this systematic review focused on respiratory hospitalizations.

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. The inclusion criteria specifically require original studies and exclude reviews and meta-analyses. The abstract clearly states this is a systematic review that 'included 196 articles in quantitative analysis.' Additionally, the outcome is mortality (all-cause, cardiovascular, respiratory, and cerebrovascular mortality), not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits as required by the inclusion criteria.

This is a review/summary chapter, not an original epidemiological study. Additionally, the outcome is mortality (including lung cancer), not respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. Fails both inclusion criteria #1 (must be original study) and #3 (outcome must be respiratory hospitalization/ED visit).

While this is an original case-crossover study examining PM2.5 exposure with quantitative effect estimates, the outcome is myocardial infarction (MI) mortality, which is a cardiovascular outcome, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visit. The study does not meet inclusion criterion #3.

Although this is an original case-crossover study that includes PM2.5 exposure and reports effect estimates with confidence intervals, the outcome is stroke hospitalization, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visits. This does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring respiratory outcomes.

The study examines PM10 (coarse particulate matter) exposure, not PM2.5 (fine particulate matter). The outcome is respiratory symptoms (cough) rather than respiratory hospitalizations or emergency department visits. While the study design is case-crossover which meets criteria, the exposure and outcome do not meet the inclusion criteria.

While this is an original epidemiological study using interrupted time-series design to examine respiratory hospital visits with quantitative effect estimates, the exposure is PM10, not PM2.5. The abstract explicitly states 'Particulate matter of 10 microns in diameter or smaller (PM10)' with no mention of PM2.5 being measured or analyzed. This does not meet the inclusion criteria requiring PM2.5 as the exposure.

The study examines hospital admissions for ischemic stroke (cardiovascular outcome), not respiratory hospitalizations. The exposure is coarse particulate matter (PM10-2.5), not PM2.5. Both the exposure and outcome do not meet the inclusion criteria.

Although this is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 exposure with quantitative effect estimates, the outcome is respiratory MORTALITY, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visit. The study does not meet inclusion criterion #3.

This is a systematic literature review/meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. It reviews 34 other articles about climatic and sociodemographic factors affecting respiratory infections. The inclusion criteria specify original epidemiological studies only, explicitly excluding reviews and meta-analyses.

This study examines PM10 (not PM2.5) exposure and mortality (not hospitalization/ED visits) as the outcome. Both the exposure and outcome do not meet the inclusion criteria for this systematic review.
Study examines PM10 (not PM2.5) exposure and respiratory mortality (not hospitalization/ED visit). Both the exposure type and outcome do not meet inclusion criteria.

This study examines PM10 (not PM2.5) as the exposure and uses years of life lost (YLL) from mortality data as the outcome, not respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. While it uses a time-series design and reports quantitative effect estimates with confidence intervals, it does not meet the exposure or outcome criteria for inclusion.

This is a meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. The inclusion criteria specifically require original epidemiological studies and exclude meta-analyses. Although it examines PM2.5 exposure and includes respiratory outcomes among others, it synthesizes data from 152 existing studies rather than presenting original research.

While this study examines respiratory hospitalizations as an outcome and uses appropriate study designs (time-series with Poisson regression and case-crossover), the exposure is PM10 (particulate matter ≤10µm) and NO2, not PM2.5 (≤2.5µm). The inclusion criteria specifically require PM2.5 exposure, and this study only examined PM10, which is a different size fraction of particulate matter.

The study examines PM10 (particulate matter <10 μm) rather than PM2.5 (≤2.5 μm) as the exposure. Additionally, the outcome is respiratory mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visits. The study fails to meet both the exposure and outcome inclusion criteria.

Study examines PM10 (not PM2.5) as the exposure and mortality (not hospitalizations/ED visits) as the outcome. Fails to meet both the exposure criterion (PM2.5) and outcome criterion (respiratory hospitalizations/ED visits).

While this is an original time-series study with effect estimates, it does not meet the inclusion criteria because: (1) the exposure is PM10, NO2, and SO2, but NOT PM2.5; and (2) the outcome is respiratory disease mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits.

This study focuses on coarse particulate matter (PM2.5-10) rather than PM2.5 as the primary exposure. Additionally, the outcome is mortality rather than respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. While the study uses a time-series design and reports effect estimates, it does not meet the critical inclusion criteria for exposure (PM2.5) and outcome (respiratory hospitalization/ED visit).

Study examines PM10 (not PM2.5) as the exposure and mortality (not hospitalization or ED visits) as the outcome. Fails to meet both inclusion criteria 2 (PM2.5 exposure) and 3 (respiratory hospitalization/ED visit outcome).
This study examines PM10 (not PM2.5) as the exposure and respiratory mortality (not hospitalization/ED visits) as the outcome. Both the exposure and outcome fail to meet the inclusion criteria.

This study examines mortality as the outcome, not respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. Additionally, the primary exposure is particle number concentration (PNC) and particle surface area concentration (PSC) rather than PM2.5 mass concentration. While PM10 is mentioned as a contrast measure, PM2.5 is not the focus of the study.

This study examines mortality as the outcome, not respiratory hospitalizations or emergency department visits. Additionally, the exposure is PM10, NO2, and O3, not PM2.5. The study fails to meet both the exposure criterion (PM2.5) and the outcome criterion (respiratory hospitalization/ED visit).
This study examines PM10 (not PM2.5) exposure and mortality (not hospitalization/ED visits) as the outcome. It fails to meet inclusion criteria for both exposure type and outcome measure.

This study examines PM10 (not PM2.5) exposure and coronary heart disease hospitalizations (not respiratory hospitalizations). It fails to meet both the exposure criterion (PM2.5) and outcome criterion (respiratory hospitalization/ED visit).

The outcome is mortality (all-cause, cardiovascular, and respiratory mortality), not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits. The study focuses on economic losses due to mortality rather than hospitalization/ED visits.

The study examines coarse particulate matter (PM2.5-10), not PM2.5, as the primary exposure. Additionally, the outcome is respiratory mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visits as required by the inclusion criteria.

While this is an original epidemiological study with PM2.5 exposure, case-crossover design, and quantitative effect estimates, the outcome is mortality (all-cause, cardiovascular, respiratory cancer) rather than respiratory hospitalization or ED visits as required by the inclusion criteria.

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. Additionally, the outcome is mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits. These violate multiple inclusion criteria.

While this is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 exposure with quantitative effect estimates, the outcome is mortality (deaths), not respiratory hospitalizations or emergency department visits. The study focuses on years of life lost and mortality counts from various causes including respiratory diseases, but does not measure hospital admissions or ED visits.

While this is an original epidemiological study with PM2.5 exposure using case-crossover design and reporting effect estimates with confidence intervals, the outcome is mortality (all-cause and specific-cause including respiratory mortality), not respiratory hospitalization or ED visit. The inclusion criteria specifically require respiratory hospitalization/ED visit as the outcome.

The study examines mortality as the outcome, not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits. The outcome is all-cause mortality in elderly aged 65 and over, which does not meet the inclusion criteria requiring respiratory hospitalization/ED visit as the outcome.

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. The inclusion criteria explicitly require original studies and exclude reviews and meta-analyses. Although the underlying studies reviewed may have examined respiratory outcomes including hospitalizations, this publication itself synthesizes other studies rather than presenting original data.

Although this is an original case-crossover study examining PM2.5 exposure with quantitative effect estimates, the outcome is mortality (death), not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits. The study examines respiratory mortality, not respiratory hospitalizations, which does not meet the inclusion criteria.

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. The inclusion criteria specifically require original epidemiological studies and exclude reviews and meta-analyses. Additionally, the outcome is mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visits.

Although this is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 exposure with quantitative effect estimates, the outcome is mortality (including respiratory mortality), not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits. The study does not meet the outcome inclusion criterion.

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. The inclusion criteria explicitly require original epidemiological studies and exclude reviews and meta-analyses. Although the underlying studies may have examined PM2.5 exposure and respiratory outcomes, this publication itself is a synthesis of existing literature.

The outcome is respiratory mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits as required by the inclusion criteria. The study examines mortality (nonaccidental, cardiovascular, and respiratory deaths) rather than hospital admissions or ED visits.

While this study meets several inclusion criteria (original epidemiological study, PM2.5 exposure, time-series design, reports effect estimates with CI), the outcome is mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits. The study examines respiratory mortality, which is a different endpoint than respiratory hospitalizations/ED visits specified in the inclusion criteria.

This appears to be a summary report of an integrated research program consisting of multiple studies (4 complementary studies), including animal studies and in vitro work, rather than a single original epidemiological study. While it mentions a time-series epidemiologic study (Ito study) examining morbidity and mortality, the outcomes are general morbidity and mortality, not specifically respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. The publication is a comprehensive program report rather than an original research article reporting specific effect estimates for respiratory hospitalizations.

This is a methodological comparison study (meta-analysis vs pooled analysis) rather than an original epidemiological study. The outcomes examined are deaths/mortality (natural causes, cardiovascular, cerebrovascular, and respiratory disease), not respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. While PM2.5 is included as an exposure and time-series design is used, the study does not meet the outcome criterion.

The study examines ozone exposure (not PM2.5 as primary exposure) and mortality outcomes (not hospitalizations or ED visits). While PM2.5 is mentioned as a covariate, the primary exposure of interest is ozone, and the outcome is respiratory mortality rather than respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits.

Although this is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 exposure with quantitative effect estimates, the outcome is respiratory MORTALITY, not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits as required by the inclusion criteria.

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis (not an original epidemiological study) examining heart failure outcomes, not respiratory hospitalizations. It fails to meet inclusion criteria 1 (original study) and 3 (respiratory outcome).

This is explicitly identified as a review article in the abstract ('have been described in this review'), not an original epidemiological study. It discusses general mechanisms and effects of PM2.5 rather than reporting original research with quantitative effect estimates for respiratory hospitalizations.

This is explicitly stated to be a review article ('In this review, we synthesize the scientific evidence...'), not an original epidemiological study. It also does not focus specifically on respiratory hospitalization or ED visits, but rather on broader health outcomes from prenatal exposure. Additionally, it does not appear to be a time-series or case-crossover study design.

This is a scoping review that synthesizes existing literature, not an original epidemiological study. Additionally, the outcomes are neurologic diseases (stroke, dementia, Parkinson disease, MS) rather than respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. Fails inclusion criteria 1 and 3.

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. The first inclusion criterion explicitly requires original epidemiological studies, and the first exclusion criterion specifically excludes reviews and meta-analyses.

This is explicitly stated as a review article focused on cellular mechanisms of PM2.5-induced cell death. It does not report original epidemiological data on respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits, does not use time-series or case-crossover design, and does not report quantitative effect estimates for clinical outcomes.

This is a meta-analysis (not an original epidemiological study) examining the association between PM2.5 and myocardial infarction (MI), not respiratory hospitalizations. It fails to meet inclusion criteria on both study type (exclusion criterion: reviews/meta-analyses) and outcome (requires respiratory hospitalization/ED visit, not cardiovascular outcomes).

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. The title explicitly states it is a 'Systematic review and meta-analysis' and the methods describe searching databases and combining risk estimates from 59 studies. This violates inclusion criterion 1 and meets the first exclusion criterion.
This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. The inclusion criteria explicitly require original studies and exclude reviews and meta-analyses.

This is explicitly stated as a review article ('The current review investigate epidemiological and experimental findings from 2016 to 2021'), not an original epidemiological study. It synthesizes findings from other studies rather than presenting original data with specific effect estimates for PM2.5 and respiratory hospitalizations.

This is explicitly stated to be a review article ('this review article was prepared', 'In this review, we focus on') focusing on PM2.5 and chronic kidney disease, not an original epidemiological study. Additionally, the outcome is kidney disease rather than respiratory hospitalization or ED visits, which does not meet the inclusion criteria.

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. It fails inclusion criterion 1. Additionally, the outcome reported is mortality (respiratory and cardiovascular deaths), not respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits as required by inclusion criterion 3.

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. The inclusion criteria specify original epidemiological studies only, and explicitly exclude reviews and meta-analyses.
This is explicitly stated as a review article ('In this review, we discussed...'), not an original epidemiological study. Reviews are excluded per the inclusion criteria.

This study examines mortality outcomes (non-accidental, cardiovascular, respiratory, and lung cancer mortality), not respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. Additionally, the study design is a cohort study examining long-term exposure, not a time-series or case-crossover design as required by the inclusion criteria.

This appears to be a narrative review, commentary, or editorial about wildfire health effects rather than an original epidemiological study. It discusses general concepts about PM2.5 from wildfires and health impacts but does not describe a specific study methodology, population, data collection, or report quantitative effect estimates with confidence intervals. The language used ('knowledge gaps remain', 'long-term research is essential') is characteristic of review/commentary articles rather than original research.

This is a review article (stated explicitly in the abstract as 'In this review, we summarize...') rather than an original epidemiological study. It focuses on toxicological mechanisms of PM2.5 effects on vascular endothelial cells, not respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. It does not meet multiple inclusion criteria.

This is a rapid review/systematic review article (not an original epidemiological study), which clearly violates the inclusion criteria. The text explicitly states it used 'an adaptation of the Cochrane rapid review methodology' and reviewed 450 manuscripts of which 15 met their criteria. Additionally, while it addresses PM2.5 exposure, the outcome is COVID-19 morbidity and mortality, not general respiratory hospitalization/ED visits.
This is a meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. Additionally, the outcome is respiratory disease mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visits.

This is explicitly identified as a review article in the title ('A review of implications for human health'). It does not present original epidemiological data, does not report quantitative effect estimates with confidence intervals, and does not describe a specific study design (time-series or case-crossover). The abstract discusses general health impacts of NH3 and PM2.5 but does not present original research findings on the association between PM2.5 exposure and respiratory hospitalizations.

This is a review article (as stated in the abstract: 'This review summarizes and discusses studies...') examining the relationship between PM2.5 and Alzheimer's disease/cognitive outcomes, not respiratory hospitalizations. It fails to meet multiple inclusion criteria: it is not an original epidemiological study, the outcome is neurological (AD-related neuropathology and cognitive outcomes) rather than respiratory hospitalization/ED visits, and it is a review rather than a primary study.

This is a meta-analysis (not an original epidemiological study) examining the association between PM exposure and myocardial infarction (cardiovascular outcome), not respiratory hospitalization. Fails inclusion criteria 1 (original study) and 3 (respiratory outcome).

This is a systematic review (not an original epidemiological study) and the outcome is ocular surface disease (conjunctivitis, dry eye, blepharitis) rather than respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits.

This is a review article (explicitly states 'In this review') focusing on cardiovascular effects and vascular smooth muscle cells, not respiratory hospitalizations. It does not meet the inclusion criteria for being an original epidemiological study with respiratory hospitalization outcomes.

This article focuses on cancer outcomes (cancer risk and cancer mortality) rather than respiratory hospitalizations or emergency department visits. Additionally, the article appears to be a narrative review or commentary that 'explores' relationships and 'proposes strategies' rather than an original epidemiological study reporting primary data analysis.

This is explicitly a review article (indicated in title and abstract), not an original epidemiological study. The outcome is cardiac developmental toxicity/congenital heart defects, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visits. Does not meet inclusion criteria on multiple grounds.

This is explicitly stated as a review article focusing on in vitro and in vivo experimental studies, not an original epidemiological study. It does not meet inclusion criterion #1 (must be original epidemiological study) and meets the first exclusion criterion (reviews are excluded). Additionally, this is not a time-series or case-crossover study design.

This is a review article, not an original epidemiological study, as explicitly stated in the objectives ('This review aims to summarize and discuss'). Additionally, the outcomes focus on post-transplant complications (organ rejection, cardiovascular disease, infection-related mortality, vitamin D deficiency) rather than respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. Does not meet inclusion criteria 1 or 3.

This is a review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. Additionally, the outcome is mortality (not hospitalization or ED visits), and the study design involves long-term cohort studies rather than time-series or case-crossover designs.

This appears to be a review/narrative article rather than an original epidemiological study. The abstract uses language typical of reviews ('This article discusses...') and focuses on general pathophysiologic mechanisms. The outcome is primarily cardiovascular disease, not respiratory hospitalization/ED visits. While some respiratory effects are mentioned, the title and focus are on cardiovascular disease. No specific study design (time-series or case-crossover) is indicated.
